question: Which element is most common in the compounds that make up ocean water, hydrogen or oxygen?

content.source_1: Seawater is approximately 96.5% water (H2O) by mass, with the remaining ~3.5% consisting of dissolved salts and gases.
content.source_2: A water molecule consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom (H2O).
content.source_3: In a water molecule, oxygen contributes about 88.8% of the molecule’s mass, while hydrogen contributes about 11.2%.
content.source_4: Major dissolved anions in seawater include sulfate (SO4^2−) and bicarbonate (HCO3−), both of which contain oxygen; dissolved oxygen gas (O2) is also present.
content.source_5: In liquid water, hydrogen atoms outnumber oxygen atoms two-to-one; hydrogen is also present in dissolved bicarbonate and trace organic compounds in seawater.
content.source_6: An oxygen atom (~16 atomic mass units) is about sixteen times as massive as a hydrogen atom (~1 atomic mass unit).
